org.ObjectLayout

Class IntrinsicObject<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.ObjectLayout.IntrinsicObject<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of the encapsulated intrinsic object

    public final class IntrinsicObject<T>
extends java.lang.Object
    IntrinsicObject are used to declare, encapsulate, and access member objects that are intrinsic to and are completely contained within other objects. IntrinsicObject semantics are designed such that the declared intrinsic member objects may be (potentially) laid out in memory such that their access can be optimized. In optimizing JVMs, the encapsulated intrinsic object instances may be "flatly" laid out within the containing objects in which they are declared, allowing for "dead reckoning" directly from the containing objects to fields within the intrinsic objects without the use of data dependant de-referencing operations.

    Note that the following rules apply to IntrinsicObject members:

    • All IntrinsicObject members must be private final fields
    • IntrinsicObject members must be initialized (either at field declaration, initialization code section, or in the containing object's constructor) using one of the construct(java.lang.Object, java.lang.String, java.lang.Class<T>) variants
    • IntrinsicObject members cannot be initialized to null
    • IntrinsicObject members cannot be initialized with the value of another IntrinsicObject member
    • IntrinsicObject members must be constructed with their containing object and their field name as parameters
    • No IntrinsicObject member can be accessed with get() until all IntrinsicObject members in declared in the containing class are correctly initialized

    Attempts to construct members with the wrong field name or containing object, or by initializing them to a value of an already initialized field will lead to a failure to construct the containing object.

    Attempts to access IntrinsicObject members before all declared IntrinsicObject fields in it's containing class have been initialized will throw an IllegalStateException detailing the cause.

      • construct

        public static <T> IntrinsicObject<T> construct(java.lang.Object containingObject,
                               java.lang.String fieldNameInContainingObject,
                               java.lang.Class<T> objectClass)
        Construct an IntrinsicObject encapsulating an intrinsic object of the given class, using a default constructor.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the intrinsic object instance being constructed
        Parameters:
        containingObject - The object instance that will contain this intrinsic object
        fieldNameInContainingObject - The name of this IntrinsicObject's field in the containing object
        objectClass - The class of the intrinsic object instance being constructed
        Returns:
        An IntrinsicObject encapsulating the newly constructed intrinsic object

      • get

        public final T get()
            throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Get a reference to the intrinsic member object
        Returns:
        The contained intrinsic object instance
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if access is attempted before all IntrinsicObject fields in the containing object have been correctly initialized.

      • makeIntrinsicObjectsAccessible

        public static <E> void makeIntrinsicObjectsAccessible(E containingObject,
                                      java.lang.Class<? extends E> containingObjectClass)
                                           throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Make all IntrinsicObject members of the containingObject, as declared in the containingObjectClass, accessible via get(). This method will verify that all declared IntrinsicObject members have been properly initialized before making any of them accessible.
        Type Parameters:
        E - The class of the containing object
        Parameters:
        containingObject - The object who's IntrinsicObject are to be made accessible
        containingObjectClass - The class fields are declared (may be a superclass of the actual object)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if one of several validation rules are not met (see details in this class's documentation above)
